metadata.title: Nanoporous CuS nano-hollow spheres as advanced material for high-performance supercapacitors

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Nanoporous CuS nano-hollow spheres as advanced material for high-performance supercapacitors
Author: Hamid Heydari Seyyed Ebrahim Moosavifard Saeed Elyasi Mohammad Shahraki
PII: S0169-4332(16)32262-0 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.apsusc.2016.10.138 Reference: APSUSC 34232
To appear in: APSUSC
Received date: 8-9-2016 Revised date: 10-10-2016 Accepted date: 21-10-2016
Please cite this article as: Hamid Heydari, Seyyed Ebrahim Moosavifard, Saeed Elyasi, Mohammad Shahraki, Nanoporous CuS nano-hollow spheres as advanced material for high-performance supercapacitors, Applied Surface Science http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2016.10.138
This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Nanoporous CuS nano-hollow spheres as advanced material for
high-performance supercapacitors
Hamid Heydari a,*, Seyyed Ebrahim Moosavifard b,*, Saeed Elyasi c, Mohammad Shahraki d
a Faculty of Sciences, Razi University, Kermanshah, Iran. b Young Researchers and Elite Club, Central Tehran Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran. c Department of chemical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran. d Department of Chemistry, University of Sistan and Baluchestan.
*Corresponding author. E-mail: info_seyyed@yahoo.com. Tel/Fax: +98 2166612673
Graphical abstract
Highlights:
 Nanoporous CuS nano-hollow spheres were synthesized by a facile method.  Nano-hollow spheres have a large specific surface area (97 m2 g−1) and nanoscale shell
thickness (< 20 nm).
 Such unique structures exhibit excellent electrochemical properties for high-performance
SCs.
Abstract: Due to unique advantages, the development of high-performance supercapacitors has stimulated a great deal of scientific research over the past decade. The electrochemical performance of a supercapacitor is strongly affected by the surface and structural properties of its electrode materials. Herein, we report a facile synthesis of high-performance supercapacitor electrode material based on CuS nano-hollow spheres with nanoporous structures, large specific surface area (97 m2 g−1) and nanoscale shell thickness (< 20 nm). This interesting electrode structure plays a key role in providing more active sites for electrochemical reactions, short ion and electron diffusion pathways and facilitated ion transport. The CuS nano-hollow spheres electrode exhibits excellent electrochemical performance including a maximum specific capacitance of 948 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, significant rate capability of 46% capacitance retention at a high current density of 50 A g−1, and outstanding long-term cycling stability at various current densities. This work not only demonstrates the promising potential of the CuSNHS electrodes for application in high-performance supercapacitors, but also sheds a new light on the metal sulfides design philosophy.
Keywords: Nanoporous; hollow spheres; CuS; supercapacitor.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Due to increasing environmental pollution and rapid depletion of fossil fuels, clean and renewable energy sources such as fuel cells, supercapacitors and lithium ion batteries have been developed intensely, in recent decades [1, 2]. Among the various energy sources, because of much longer cycle life, safer operation, lower maintenance cost and higher power density, supercapacitors (SCs) have attracted much more attention [3, 4]. Supercapacitors, based on the charge storage mechanism, classified into two types: Electrical double layer capacitors (EDLC) and pseudocapacitors. Pseudocapacitors such as metal oxides/hydroxides due to contribution of redox reactions exhibit much higher specific capacitance and energy density than EDLCs (carbonaceous materials that store energy by electrostatic charge separation [2, 5]. Presently, due to more complex valence states compared to oxides, high electrochemical performance, rich valences and good chemical stability [6], various transition metal sulfides such as NiS [7], CoS [8], NiCo2S4 [9], CuCo2S4 [10], SnS [11], CuS [12] and ZnS [13] have attracted increasing attention as pseudocapacitive electrode materials. Among these transition metal sulfides, CuS is a promising candidate owing to its low cost, elemental abundance, metallike electronic conductivity (10-3 S cm−1), various shapes at the nanoscale [12, 14]. Raj et al. grew CuS nanoplates on FTO substrates with a specific capacitance of 73 F g−1 and poor cycling stability (13.9% loss after 100 CV cycles) [12]. Huang et al. synthesized CuS nanosheets assisted by CTAB and SDBS surfactants with a specific capacitance of 379 and 232 F g−1, and 40% and 38% loss after the 500 cycles, respectively [15]. Zhu et al. prepared CuS nanoneedles on a CNT backbone with a specific capacitance of 122 F g−1 and excellent cycling stability [14]. Hsu et al. reported CuS nanowire arrays on Cu foil with a maximum specific capacitance of 305 F g−1 and 13% loss after 5000 cycles [16]. Peng et al. synthesized multi-structural CuS@polypyrrole composites with a specific capacitance of 427 F g−1 and 12 % loss after 1000 cycles [17]. Peng et al. reported hierarchical structures of CuS that demonstrated a maximum specific capacitance of 597 F g−1 with 20% loss after 1000 cycles [18]. The active sites for electrochemical reactions, transport/diffusion paths, accessibility of electrolyte and kinetics are the most important factors that affect the electrochemical performance of supercapacitor electrodes [19, 20]. It has been accepted that these factors strongly depend on the specific surface area, pore-size distribution and wall thickness of
electrode materials [21, 22]. Therefore, with designing of such morphologies that have more specific surface area, nanopores and thin wall thickness can intensely improve the performance of electrode materials [23, 24]. In this view, hollow sphere morphologies with nanopores can be a promising candidates. Herein, we report a nanoporous CuS with nano-hollow sphere (NHS) morphology as a high-performance supercapacitor electrode material, for the first time. This electrode has a high surface area and narrow pore size distribution with slight thickness that exhibits ultrahigh specific capacitance (948 F g−1 at 1 A g−1) and excellent cycle life at various current densities. This study demonstrates the great potential of CuS-NHS in the development of high performance energy storage systems.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental 2.1. Synthesis of CuS-NHS
sections.text:
In a typical procedure for the synthesis of CuS-NHS, a solution was first prepared by mixing
50 mL of ethylene glycol (EG, Merck), 0.3 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, MW= 40000, Merck) and 4 mmol of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Merck). Then, the solution was heated to and maintained at 175 °C under vigorous magnetic stirring for 20 min. After, a given amount of thiourea (with a thiourea : copper molar ratio of 2 : 1) was quickly injected and the mixture was transferred into a stainless-steel autoclaves and maintained at 160 °C for 24 h. Finally, the resulting black precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and distilled water several times. For the synthesis of bulk CuS, the above procedure was repeated with addition of sodium hydroxide (40 mmol, Merck) and ascorbic acid (8 mmol, Merck), and without addition of PVP.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text: Prepared samples were structurally characterized using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Philips X’pert diffractometer with Cu K𝛼 radi-ation (𝜆 = 0.154 nm) generated at 40 kV and 30 mA with a step size of 0.04° s−1). Nitrogen adsorption/desorption and specific surface area were carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP-2010 apparatus from the multipoint Brunauer− Emmett−Teller (BET) method; and the pore size distribution was derived from the desorption isotherm using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The morphologies and structural investigations of the samples were performed by a Zeiss field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and a Philips EM 208 transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDAX).

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
For electrochemical measurements, the electrodes were prepared by mixing active material, acetylene black, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) with a mass ratio of 85:10:5. A 10 % solution of the mixture in acetone was prepared and coated on nickel foam as the current collector by a coater (M.T.D.I.89, Modern Technology Development Institute, Iran) and then dried in 120 °C for 2 h. The prepared electrodes were used as the working electrodes; and all electrochemical investigations were performed in aqueous 6 M KOH solution on a BioLogic VSP 300 potentiostat/galvanostat device using a three electrode system with Hg/HgO electrodes and platinum plates were used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The specific capacitances (Csp), energy densities (ED, W h kg-1) and power densities (PD, W kg-1) were calculated from the discharge curves using the following equations: 𝐶𝑠𝑝 = IΔ𝑡
mΔ𝑉 (1)
𝐸𝐷 = CspΔ𝑉
2
2 (2)
𝑃𝐷 = 𝐸𝐷
𝛥𝑡 (3)
where I is the discharge current (A), ∆t is the discharge time (s), ∆V is the potential window (V), and m is the mass loading (g).

sections.heading: 3.1. Synthesis mechanism
sections.text: Our synthetic strategy to prepare CuS-NHS is based on the polyol route [25, 26] and Kirkendall effect [27, 28] as shown in scheme 1. In the first step, the primary Cu2O nanocrystals synthesized from polyol reaction (Equation (1)) prefer to aggregate into spherical nanospheres due to the effect of EG solvent and PVP. 2Cu(NO3)2 + 3HOCH2CH2OH → Cu2O + 4NO2 + 3CH3COOH + 3H2O (1) In the second step, CuS nano-hollow spheres are formed (Equation (2)) through the Kirkendall effect owning to the faster mobility of O2– anions than that of S2– which leads to the loss of the inner volume. Cu2O + (H2N)2C=S → CuS (2)

sections.heading: 3.2. Structural characterization
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was used to characterize the crystallinity and phase purity of the as prepared nano-hollow sphere and bulk CuS samples. As shown in Fig 1a, All diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns of the both samples can be well indexed to the standard pattern of covellite type CuS (JCPDS card No: 06-0464, hexagonal phase, a =b= 3.792 Å and c = 16.344 Å) with no characteristic peaks assigned to possible impurities such as Cu2O, Cu2S or CuO. The good crystallinity of both samples was confirmed by the sharp and intense peaks in their XRD patterns; but, the broader diffraction peaks of the nano-hollow sphere sample verify its smaller size crystallites. The composition and the purity of the resulting nano-hollow spheres was further evaluated by EDAX analysis as shown in Fig. 1b. Only the Cu and S peaks are observed in this spectrum, suggesting that the sample is composed of Cu and S elements. According to the quantification of the peaks, the atomic ratio of the Cu element versus S is about 1:1 (50.8 : 49.2), which is very close to the stoichiometry of CuS. The porosity of the as prepared nano-hollow spheres and bulk samples were investigated by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms. As shown in Fig. 1c, bulk sample has a type II isotherm that is characteristic for non-porous/macroporous materials, while nano-hollow sphere sample exhibits a typical IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop that is characteristic for mesoporous/nanoporous materials [29, 30]. The BET specific surface area of the nanoporous CuS-NHS is calculated to be 97 m2 g−1, which is much higher than that of bulk CuS (8 m2 g−1). The pore size distribution of the nano-hollow spheres, calculated by the BJH method (inset of Fig. 1c), reveals a narrow pore size distribution centered at 4 nm. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) was employed to explore the morphology of the as-prepared sample. The typical FESEM image of the nanoporous CuS sample is shown in Fig. 1d. From this image it can be clearly observed that the nanoporous CuS sample is composed of a large number of uniform spheres with the diameter of about 80-100 nm, without any by-products such as bulks or nonspherical shapes. In order to obtain more information about the specific morphology and the interior structure of the samples, TEM analysis was performed. As shown in Fig. 1e, the contrast difference between the dark edges and the pale center demonstrates that the nanospheres have a porous hollow structures. The shell thicknesses of the nano-hollow spheres are estimated to be less than 20 nm. Furthermore,
the well-recorded selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (inset of Fig. 1e) reveals the single-crystalline nature of individual nanoparticles in the CuS-NHS. Fig. 1f shows the dense, non-porous, micro-meter size and agglomerated particles of the bulk CuS sample. The high specific surface area, thin and nanoporous shells are the key factors in energy storage systems providing more active sites for electrochemical reactions, rapid electrolyte transport and shorter diffusion paths [19, 31, 32]. Therefore, it can be predicted that nanoporous CuS-NHS might show much better electrochemical behavior than bulk sample, and can be a promising candidate as a high-performance supercapacitor electrode material.

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical Properties
sections.text:
Electrochemical evaluation of the as prepared nano-hollow spheres and bulk CuS were investigated in a three-electrode cell containing a 6 M KOH aqueous solution as the electrolyte. Fig. 2a shows the typical cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the current collector (Ni foam), CuS-NHS and bulk CuS electrodes at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. As can be seen the current collector has no capacitance contribution due to its negligible CV integrated area as compared with those of the other two CuS electrodes. Also, when comparing the CV integrated area of the CuS-NHS electrode with that of the bulk CuS electrode, significant enhancement in its specific capacitance is obviously visible. Furthermore, strong redox peaks observed in the CV curves of the both CuS electrodes, different from the nearly rectangular CV shapes for EDLCs, reveal the pseudocapacitive characteristics of these electrodes [15, 33]. Fig. 2b represents typical CV curves of the CuS-NHS electrode measured at various scan rates ranging from 10 to 100 mV s−1. As shown, when the scan rate increases from 10 to 100 mV s−1, the shape of the CV curves is not significantly influenced. This phenomenon indicates the improved mass transport, high rate capability and reversibility of the CuS-NHS electrode [19, 34]. As a reliable method to estimate the capacitance performance of electrodes, galvanostatic charge/discharge (CD) measurements were performed for calculation of the specific capacitances, rate capability and cyclic life of the electrodes. The CD curves of the CuS-NHS electrode at various current densities of 1 to 50 A g−1 in the voltage range of -0.2 - 0.4 V are illustrated in Figs. 2c and d. The nonlinear shape of the CD curves confirms that the pseudocapacitance mechanism is the main source of charge storage in the CuS-NHS electrode, which is in good agreement with the CV results. Furthermore, low iR drop even at a high current density of 20 A g−1 (Fig. 2d) indicates the high conductivity and low internal resistance
of this electrode [35]. From the discharge tests, the ultrahigh specific capacitance of 948 F g−1 was calculated at the discharge current density of 1 A g−1 for CuS-NHS electrode, which is much higher than that of bulk CuS (179 F g−1) and most of the previously reported CuS electrode materials [12, 14-18]. The specific capacitances of the electrodes at various current densities, in order to comparison and presentation of their rate capabilities, were illustrated in Fig. 2d. The specific capacitances of CuS-NHS electrode are 948, 874, 765, 671, 562, and 433 F g−1 at current densities of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, and 50 A g−1, respectively; also, the specific capacitances of bulk CuS electrode are 179, 140, 101, 73, 52 and 31 F g−1 at current densities of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20 and 50 A g−1, respectively. As seen, the specific capacitances of CuS-NHS electrode, in all current densities, are higher than those of bulk sample. Although the specific capacitances of the electrodes decreases with increasing current densities, due to insufficient involvement of active material in redox reaction [36, 37], however the CuS-NHS electrode still retains 46% (433 F g−1) of the its initial capacitance even at a high current density of 50 A g−1. This demonstrates an excellent rate capability for the CuS-NHS electrode. Power density and energy density are very important parameters of supercapacitors to evaluate their operational performance/efficiency [38]. In order to represent and compare the overall performance of the CuS electrodes, the Ragone plot (that is the plot of energy density against power density) was shown in Fig. 2f. As seen, the energy densities of the CuS-NHS electrode are much higher than those of bulk CuS electrode. In detail, a maximum energy density of 47.4 W h kg−1 was achieved for the CuS-NHS electrode at a power density of 0.3 kW kg−1, which is much higher than that of bulk sample (9 W h kg−1). Cycling performance is an important factor for evaluating a supercapacitor electrode material. To further indicate the advantages of the CuS-NHS electrode architecture on its electrochemical behavior, the long-term cycling stability of the electrodes was tested using sequential CD measurements. As shown in Fig. 3a, with 9.2 % capacitance loss, the cycling stability of the CuS-NHS electrode in the first 2000 cycles at a current density of 2 A g−1 is much higher than that of bulk electrode (59 % capacitance loss) and most of the previously reported CuS electrode materials [15, 17, 18, 33, 39, 40]. The further investigation of the cycling stability of the CuSNHS electrode was performed over 3000 cycles at various current densities of 5, 10 and 2 A g−1. As can be seen, in the current density of at 5 A g−1 (third 1000 cycles) the capacitance decreased to 91.3 % of its initial value, and at the end of the forth 1000 cycles (at 10 A g−1), the
electrode retained about 92 % of its capacitance. After 4000 continuous cycles at various current densities, when the current density was turned back to 2 A g−1, the electrode recovered 95.6 % of its primary capacitance and finally, 95.5 % of the capacitance maintained after fifth 1000 cycles at 2 A g−1. According to these results, remarkable long-term cycling stability of the CuSNHS electrode is demonstrated. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed to further characterization of the electrochemical behavior of the electrodes. Fig. 3b shows the Nyquist plots of the CuS-NHS (before and after cycling) and bulk electrodes at open circuit potential. A semicircle followed by a linear slope was appeared in the spectra of the both electrodes. Semicircle at high frequencies corresponds to the charge transfer resistance (Rct) [41], linear slope at the medium or low frequencies and steeper line (vertical line for an ideal capacitor) at low frequencies correspond to the Warburg impedance (Zw) [42] and the capacitive nature of the electrodes, respectively. Accordingly, the smaller charge transfer resistance and the lower equivalent series resistance (ESR, the intercept of the Nyquist curve on the real axis, inset of Fig. 3b) of the CuSNHS electrode demonstrate its larger electro-active surface area and higher electrical conductivity. In addition, from the more vertical line at the low frequency region of the CuSNHS spectra can be found that the nanoporous structure of the CuS-NHS electrode facilitates the mass transfer of the electrolyte [20, 21]. Furthermore, the excellent cycling stability of the CuS-NHS electrode was further confirmed by its nearly identical Nyquist plots before and after cycling. All of these results demonstrate the excellent pseudocapacitance characteristic features of the CuS-NHS as a high-performance supercapacitor electrode material. This outstanding electrochemical performance of the CuS-NHS electrode including ultrahigh specific capacitance and remarkable long-term cycling stability can be attributed to its nanohollow sphere morphology with unique properties, such as nanoporous structure (contain a narrow pore size distribution centered at 4 nm), high surface area (97 m2 g−1) and thin shell thickness (< 20 nm) with single-crystal nanostructures. As shown in Scheme 2, nanoporous structures minimize the diffusion distance from the external electrolyte to the interior surfaces by acting as ion-buffering reservoirs which enhances the accessibility of electrolyte not only at its surface but also throughout the entire material [19, 20]; ions can enter from these nanopores into the hollow spheres and thus shorten their diffusion distance to access the electrode surface [43, 44]. High specific surface area improves the utilization of the active material by providing
more active sites with larger interfacial area between the electrode material and the electrolyte ions [21, 22]. Nanosized shell thickness leads to faster kinetics and higher conductivity by providing short transport pathways for electrons [10, 19], and its single-crystal nanostructures can improve the stability of the electrodes [45].
Conclusions CuS nano-hollow sphere electrodes have developed with nanoporous structure, high specific surface area, and nanosized shell thickness. Due to unique structural features that improve the utilization of the active material, minimize the diffusion distance and provide faster kinetics and higher conductivity, the CuS-NHS electrodes exhibit high specific capacitance of 948 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, outstanding rate capability, high energy density and remarkable cycling stability at different current densities. We believe that CuS-NHS electrodes are a promising candidate for application in high-performance supercapacitors owning to their distinguished electrochemical performance. This work also gives some insights into the design of metal sulfide electrodes used in a various range of applications such as catalysis, lithium ion batteries, biosensors, gas sensors, and other electronic devices.

referenceMentions.context: Due to increasing environmental pollution and rapid depletion of fossil fuels, clean and renewable energy sources such as fuel cells, supercapacitors and lithium ion batteries have been developed intensely, in recent decades [1, 2].

Due to increasing environmental pollution and rapid depletion of fossil fuels, clean and renewable energy sources such as fuel cells, supercapacitors and lithium ion batteries have been developed intensely, in recent decades [1, 2].
Among the various energy sources, because of much longer cycle life, safer operation, lower maintenance cost and higher power density, supercapacitors (SCs) have attracted much more attention [3, 4].

As shown in Scheme 2, nanoporous structures minimize the diffusion distance from the external electrolyte to the interior surfaces by acting as ion-buffering reservoirs which enhances the accessibility of electrolyte not only at its surface but also throughout the entire material [19, 20]; ions can enter from these nanopores into the hollow spheres and thus shorten their diffusion distance to access the electrode surface [43, 44].

metadata.abstractText: Due to unique advantages, the development of high-performance supercapacitors has stimulated a great deal of scientific research over the past decade. The electrochemical performance of a supercapacitor is strongly affected by the surface and structural properties of its electrode materials. Herein, we report a facile synthesis of high-performance supercapacitor electrode material based on CuS nano-hollow spheres with nanoporous structures, large specific surface area (97 m g) and nanoscale shell thickness (< 20 nm). This interesting electrode structure plays a key role in providing more active sites for electrochemical reactions, short ion and electron diffusion pathways and facilitated ion transport. The CuS nano-hollow spheres electrode exhibits excellent electrochemical performance including a maximum specific capacitance of 948 F g at 1 A g, significant rate capability of 46% capacitance retention at a high current density of 50 A g, and outstanding long-term cycling stability at various current densities. This work not only demonstrates the promising potential of the CuSNHS electrodes for application in high-performance supercapacitors, but also sheds a new light on the metal sulfides design philosophy.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
